cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

row.cell:
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
Le réseau de cable télégraphiques sous-marins de cette compagnie
constitue le moyen de communication le plus
direct et le plus rapide d'Egypte pour l'Europe, l'Amérique
du Nord et du Sud, L,Afrique orientale, méridionale
et occidentale, les Indes, l'Australie, la Nouvelle-Zélande, la
Chine et le Japon.
Pour assurer une transmission rapide, les télégrammes
doivent porter l'indication Viâ Eastern.
Voir le temps moyen de transmission le plus récent jusqu'à
Londres au belletin journalier publié dans ce journal.
STATIONS EN EGYPTE. Alexandrie, le Caire, Suez,
Port-Tewfik, Port-Said, Suakin. Bureau principal à Londres.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: The following steamers are expected to leave Port Said on or about the following dates:--
Port-Said to London via Brindisi
The BRINDISI steamer leaves PORT-SAID after arrival of Indian Mail. Combined steamer and sleeping car fare from PORT-SAID to LONDON via BRINDISI or via MARSEILLES £25.9.11
To the East.

The Mail Steamers leave SUEZ for ADEN and BOMBAY every Wednesday, and for AUSTRALIA and CHINA every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for CALCUTTA, fortnightly, and another for JAPAN. Passengers can embark at PORT-SAID.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS (Athens), SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Belgrade, Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
Steamers leave Suez every Thursday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, calling as required at TOR (for Mount Sinai) and YAMBO, and continuing in alternate weeks to SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd's Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste-Venice Line

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Paris, London, Naples, Rome. Arrival Trieste Wednesday noon connecting with Vienna Express (Trieste-Ostende through carriage) and expresses to Italy and Germany.
Alexandria-Patras-Brindish-Triste Line
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 7th and 21st December.
Far East Line

(Departure from Suez). To Aden, Kurashee, Bombay, Colombo, Penang, Singapore, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Yokohama, Kobe about Dec. 5, 1904 and 3rd Jan. 05. To Aden and Bombay continental service about 9th Dec 1904, and 9th Jan. 1905. To Aden, Karachi, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon, and Colombo about 20th January, 1905.
East African Line.
To Aden, Mombassa, Zanzibar, Beira, Delagoa Bay, Durban, about 4th Dec. 1904 and 3rd Jan. 05.

The Bank undertakes all banking business in Egypt, Greece,
etc. Interest, on cash deposits: 3 % per ann. at sight; 3 1/2 %
per ann. for 6 months ; 4 % per ann. for 12 months ; 5 % per
ann. for 3 years and over. Savings Bank Branch receives de-
posits at 3 1/2 % per ann., from P.T. 30 to P.T. 10,000. 23538-19-1.905

MORNING & NEAL'S.
Trade Mark — "INVINCIBLE."
MANUFACTURERS OF THE LARGEST AND MOST EFFICIENT
Centrifugal Pumping Machinery In the world, suitable fcr all purposes, including RECLAMATION, DRAINAGE, IRRIGATION, SEWAGE WORKS, GRAVING & FLOATING DOCKS, MINES, & ALL MANUFACTURING PURPOSES.
These Pumps can be driven by Steam, Gas, Oil, Water, Electricity, or other power, for Lifts of from 1 ft. to 500ft., and from 5 to 500,000 Gallons a Minute. Makers of the Mex Pumps.
Results Guaranteed.
Over 50 Years' Practical Experience.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: GHEZIREH PALACE HOTEL.
div.p: On the bank of the Nile, Formerly the Palace of the late Khedive Ismail. Transformed into a luxurious hotel.
SPLENDID PARK.
Renowned for its afternoon-teas on the West Balcony overlooking the Park. Excellend Tsigane Orchestra, Motor-car running to Shepheard's Hotel and vice-verse.

div.head:
PAGNON'S HOTELS,
LUXOR.
div.p: LUXOR HOTEL.–This old established hotel, accommodating 130 guests, is situated amid beautiful gardens with entrance on the river. Resident Doctor and Anglican Chaplain, Billiard Rooms, Bar, Electric Light, and all the conveniences of a first-class European Hotel. Tennis Court.
KARNAK HOTEL.–Under same management. Beautifully situated on river. Nice gardens. Guests taken on pension. Moderate terms. Excursions arranged to Thebes, Karnak, etc.

Fire-proof, Drained to the Sea, Lifts, Electric Light, English and French Billiards, Fresh and Salt Water Baths.
The Coolest Summer Residence in Egypt.
Special terms to Cairo Residents and their families desirous of enjoying the cool air and sea bathing during the summer months.
Dragomans in Hotel Uniform Meet all Trains and Steamers.

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT

REMARKS.
Fine weather prevailed yesterday. From midnight to 9 a.m. there was a calm wind and sea. Dense fog and damp conditions prevailed. Barometer steady.

div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber's address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.

Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1904.

div.head: 'BALLONS D'ESSAI"
div.p: The Russian Press has been very active lately in demanding the instand despatch of a part, at least, of the Black Sea Squadron to join or follow Admiral Rodjestvensky's fleet on a cruise to Eastern waters. Greay Britain, according to most Russian journalists, is the sole Power that will make any diplomatic objections to the passing of the Bosphorus and Dardanelles by the Russian division, and Captain Klado, since then under fifteen days arrese, informs his public that the British foreign polocy is now a matter of snarls and grimaces, alarming but scarcely to be called dangerous. Whether the Black Sea Fleet is in a condition to reach Far Eastern waters we leave to naval experts to decide, but the calm assumption that Great Britain will permit a squadron to pass in defiance of treaty obligations and endanger the very existance of her ally, would be amusing were it not part of a scheme to sow dissention between the two naval Powers. The Muscovite Press, always awaiting inspiration, has shown remarkable unamity in denouncing the "perfidy" shown by England in her tretament of her unfortunate ally. The case of the Caroline, the fact that British shippers have industriously supplied the Port Arthur garrison with provisions, the shipping of coal for the Baltic Fleet from Cardiff, the placing of a Russian order of $150,000 for heavy guns with the firms of Vickers and Maxim, are all quoted as proofs of our guile, and the passage of the

div.head: Where to Winter in Egypt
The Tewfik Palace Hotel.
div.p: Telephone No. 5 Helouan.
Tel. Address "Tewfik Helouan." ABC Code, 11th Edition
HELOUAN
Half-an-hour from Cairo
HOURLY TRAIN SERVICE
SPECIAL FEATURES.
REST AND HEALTHIEST SITUATION IN HELOUAN
PERFECT SANITARY ARRANGEMENTS
SEPARATE BALCONIES AND BATHROOMS TO MOST OF THE BEDROOMS
MAGNIFICENT PRIVATE GARDENS
WARMED THROUGHOUT BY A SPECIAL SYSTEM OF RADIATORS
ELECTRIC LIGHT THROUGHOUT
Moderate Terms, from 10/3
Office in Cairo- Stephenson & Co.,(English Chermiata) Opera Square.
General Manager-C.Aquilina, telephone 81.
(late of Thos. Cook & Son).
Dardanelles will, in the opinion of Russian journalists, be viewed with resignation, if not with complacency, by a perjured Government.

"In vain is the net spread in the sight of the bird." The Japanese are unlikely to be duped by these statements or appalled by the menace of the Black Sea Squadron, and though Russian statesmen inform eager journalisrts that We shall astonish the world by out moderation in the hour of victory, the hour of victory has not yet come, and Japan remains unmoved in her determination to check the Russian advance on Korea and N. China. Meanwhile, the Dardanelles question may yet cause trouble. Austria is interedted in protecting the Russian ingress to the Mediterranean, but to the suzerains of Egypt the very possibility is unpleasant to think of. A Russian fleet allowed free ingress and egress to and from the Black Sea would enable the Tsar's Govermnent to levy blackmail on Constantinople, while the Power that is now in occupation in Egypt cannot be indifferent to the risk of a naval raid on Egypt or the Syrian Coast in the absense of the whole or part of the Mediterranean squadron. The naval balance of power has shifted North, our next naval combat may be in the Atlantic, and should the treaty clauses, that forbid the Black Sea Fleet to pass the Kavals, be ever aborgated, the fortification of Port-Said and Alexandria, or better, a large increase of the Mediterranean Squadron, will be necessary.

div.head: THE PHARMACY REGULATIONS
div.p: We understand that Sir Horace Pinching'd reply to the Cairo pharmacists' committee will be delivered to-day or to-morrow. It is being awaited with great interest, and it will be interesting to see whether its decisions satisfy the majority of those concerned. The point at issue netween the Sanitary Department and the pharmacists is this. Are persons who have no knowledge whatever of drugs and their properties to be allowed to control pharmacies? The pharmacists, for the most part, urge that this should be forbidden, and that, in accordance with the practice usual in all Continental countries, no person should be allowed to own a pharmacy without holding a pharmaceutical diploma. Sir Horace Pinching, on the other hand, takes the view that no such qualifications should be demanded of the proprietor qui proprietor, but that, should he have anything whatever to do with the management od the pharmacy or pharmacies which are his property, he must first satisfy the Sanitary Department that he possesses expert knowledge. Should he not possess this, he cannpt interfere in any way with the management of the shop, and must leave this to a qualified pharmacist. The Director-General of the Sanitary Department holds that these conditions will elsure the safety of the public as dar as is humanly possible, and quotes Englans and the United States as countries where the proprietor of a chemist's shop is not necessarily an expert, but where the management is all that concernt the articles solely is in expert hands. The pharmacists of Cairo seem inclined to argue that the conditions in these counteies differ widely from those in Egypt, and that in practice it will be difficult or impossible to prevent the interference of the proprietor, if he should be minded to interfere. Will an expert-assistant risk the loss of hisplace, of his proprietor chooses to overstep the limits laid down in the new Pharmacy Regulations?

div.head: PORT ARTHUR
DESTRUCTION OF FLEET
FEELING IN RUSSIA
div.p: ST. PETERSBURG, DECEMBER 13 .

The publication in Russia of the destruction of the Port Arthur fleet, which was hithero unknown except to a small circle, created consternation. Admiral Rodjestvensky's mission is now regarded as foredoomed to disaster.

div.head: THE BALTIC FLEET
ARRIVAL AT MOSSAMEDES
div.p: MOSSAMEDES, December, 13.
Admiral Rodjestvensky with 21 vessles has arrived here. (Reuter).
MOSSAMEDES, December 13.
Twenty vessles of the Baltic Fleet have arrived. (Havas).

div.head: GENERAL NEWS
div.p: "SCENE” IN HUNGARIAN CHAMBER.
FURNITURE SMASHED.

BUDAPEST, December 13. In view of the resolve of the Premier, M. Tisza, to introduce new rules against the 2 obstruction of Deputies, the Opposition entered the House a quarter of an hour before the meeting was to take place. They smashed the Presidential dais and table, together with the ministerial chairs, to atoms. They drove out the attendants with legs from the tables. Four attendants were wounded. In consequence of this disturbance, no sitting was held. (R.)

BUDAPEST, December 13. The members of the Opposition forced an entrance into the Chamber of Representatives and, after having chased the Presidential guard out, they smashed the dais and the desks. The sitting was adjourned. (Havas.)
M. DE PLEHVE'S ASSASSINATION.
MURDERER SENTENCED.

ST. PETERSBURG, December 13. The trial of Sassonoff, the assassin of M. det Plehve, and his accomplice, Sirkoski, began here this afternoon. There was a great crowd in the approaches to the Law Courts, which were patrolled by the police. The garrison was ready, but no disturbance took place.
Sassonoff was condemned to penal servitude for life and Sikorski to 20 years. (Reuter.)
NORTH SEA COMMISSION.
BEGINS 'WORK IN JANUARY.

Paris, December 13. The North Sea Commission will probably megt on the 20th inst., in order to chose the 1: 6tk Admiral and to decide apon the procedure to Ve followed. The real work will begin in January.
FRENCH INCOME TAX.
Paris, December 13. M. Rouvier defended the income tax in the Chamber of Deputies. (Havas.)
THE KHEDIVE

The Khedive left Montazah Palace yesterday | at about 10 a.m. by special train for Marioutt to inspect his estates there. · His Highness passed the might at Sidi Aboul Rahman and will return this evening to Montazah.
His Highness has bestowed the 4th class of the Order of the Medjidieh on Mr. Hallam, Sub-Inspector of Sennar.
It is currently rumoured that his Highness is desirous of appointing Adly Pasha Yeghen, Governor of Cairo, as successor to Hassan Pasha Assem.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: GYMKHANA.---The next Mena House Gymkhana will be held on Friday, January 6.
QUARANTINE restrictions have been enforced on arrivals in Egyptian ports from Rangoon.
The BRINDISI Mail arrives this evening and will be distributed at the G.P.O., Alexandria, at 7.45 a.m. to-morrow,
RAILWAY COMMISSION.--The report of the Railway Commission was handed to the Ministry of Finance yesterday.
New Doctors.--Messrs. Felix Gottschlich and F. Malezian, doctors, have been licensed to exercise their profession in Egypt.
KHEDIVE'S ACCESSION FETES.- The total subscriptions collected by the Accession Fetes Committee now amount to L.E. 497.

Book on Egypt.--"The Agricultural Wealth of Egypt and the Sudan" is the title of a brochure written by Mr. Charles Tuchmann, It deals largely with the importance and prospects of cotton-growing in these territories, and with the rubber, gum, and mineral productions of the Sudan.

Mishap To P. & O. STEAMER.- The P. &0. S.S. Sardinia (Capt. C. C. Talbot, R.N.R.) arrived at Port Said on Monday evening after a difficult passage through the Canal with only one propeller, the other having been lost while anchoring in Suez Bay. She has proceeded on her voyage to London with the remaining propeller, her speed being reduced to 8 knots.

TELEPHONE Co. or Egypt. - The London Stock Exchange Committee have appointed to-day as a special settling day for Telephone Co. of Egypt, £60,000 Four and a Half per Ct. Deb. stock. They have also ordered the above-mentioned security to be quoted in the Official List.

GUARANTEES.-The public confidence is always in proportion to the given guarantees, and there is much truth in the saying, "A good name is better than riches." We may say that much of the success of the Berlitz schools is due to the universal reputation of its admirable method. The results already obtained in Egypt, by the pupils who have been learning English, French, German, Italian, etc., eto., are an ample proof of the success of these schools in Alexandria (26, Rue Eglise Copte), and at Cairo (1, Sharia Kamel). (Advt.).

A. L. M. & D. S.-On Monday next, 19th inst., Mr. Atwood will lecture at the Scotch High School, in the Missala quarter, on "A Great Philanthropic Work in London.” We understand that the kind of work that formed the subject of our leading article last Saturday will be fully dealt with by the lecturer, who will have much to say of great importance to all interested in philanthropic work, espe. cially that done in the direction of rescuing destitute and waif children from their wretched surroundings, and giving them the chance of becoming respectable members of society. We hope to see a large attendance of members of the Alexandria Literary, Musical, and Dramatic Society and their friends. Members will be admitted free, non-members on payment of P.T. 2.

div.head: PRINCE LEOPOLD'S VISIT
ARRIVAL IN CAIRO
div.p: H.R.H. Prince Leopold of Battenberg arrived at Port Said yesterday afternoon by the Arabia and left by train for Cairo.
His Royal Highness, who was accompanied by Dr. J. M. Stenhouse, M. B., reached Cairo last night by the 11.15 train from Port Said. His Highness is staying at the Hotel d'Angleterre

div.head: ARMY OF OCCUPATION
div.p: Lieutenant-Colonel and Brevet Colonel Antonio Gatt, Royal Malta Artillery, has retired on retired pay.
Colonel W. A. May, C.B., R.A.M.C., has been granted leave of absence, in extension from 30th inst. to February 9, for the recovery of his health.

The following officers have been recorded to the War Office as having passed the tactica test required for promotion to the rank of Lieut.-Colonel, at Cairo, on 14th November Tajor G. T. G. Edwards, 20th Hussars ; Major H.V.S. Ormond, 1st Lancashire Fusiliers lajor H. P. Hancox, 2nd Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers ; Major E. R. O. Ludlow, A.S.C.

div.head: YOUSBASHI ARMSTRONG'S DEATH
div.p: The greatest astonishment has been caused owing to the circumstances attending the death of Yousbashi Armstrong, which, as we announced on Monday, took place at the German Deaconesses' Hospital, Alexandria, on Sunday. Only a few days ago the deceased was getting on well, and wrote to his friends that he was on the way to recovery from the attack { scarlet fever from which he had been suffering. He was judged by his doctor to be convalescent and had been allowed to see some of his acquaintances.

The question at once occurs by what mishance he could have caught one of the most horrible forms of infectious malady known to humanity, for the small-pox to which he fell victim was the most loathsome type of that ill disease. Lately he had written to his friends full of hope as to his speedy departure from the hospital. When, therefore, it was announced last week that he had contracted a fresh disease, the news was received with astonishment. He was so much liked, and such a good type of a young Englishman, that the circumstances attending his sudden death have caused a great deal of poignant interest to a large circle of his friends and acquaintances in the English colony here. But in justice to the German Hospital at Alexandria it may be ated that in England no small-pox hospital is considered safe within a distance of half a mile so infectious is that disease. A case of smallpox was being treated at the hospital while Yousbashi Armstrong was convalescent, and he must have caught the infection in the air, -at least so it is presumed.

div.head: SUDAN APPOINTMENTS
div.p: Mr. Maxwell Fleming, an Edinburgh advocates has been appointed a Civil judge in the Sudan:
Mr. Graham, Inspector of Sennar, has been appointed a 1st-class magistrate.
Bimbashi Comyn, of the Dromedary Corps, and Bimbashi Scott-Hill have been transferred to the Sudan.
Mr. Wood has been appointed Sub-Inspector of Forests.
The rank of Kaimakam has been conferred on Bimbashi MacEwen Bey and Bimbashi Fell, Inspectors of the Ghezireh and Bahr el-Ghazal provinces.

div.head: BUBOINC PLAGUE
div.p: One case of plague was reported at Suez and one in the Toukh district yesterday.
To-day another case (fatal) is reported from Port Said.

div.head: MENA NOTES
div.p: The band performances at Mena House will begin to-morrow (Thursday). Mr. Bracale has specially engaged in Italy a fine band of 12 musicians and a conductor for this purpose. As already mentioned, the band will also play during luncheon on Thursdays and Sundays.
Four hundred invitations have been issued for the dance which will be held at Mena House on the 21st inst., at 9.30 p.m. Special trams will run on that night at 11.50 p.m., 12.50 am., and 1.50 a.m.

div.head: GRAND CONTINENTAL HOTEL
div.p: By kind permission of Lieut.-Colonel G. M. Mackenzie, commanding, and officers 2nd Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, the Band will play the following programme on the Terrace, Grand Continental Hotel, on Thursday afternoon from 4 to 6 p.m.
Grand Processional March - The Silver Trumpete -Viviani.
Danoe de Czechs - Kottann.
Overture to the drama-Mozart - Sappó. (On motives from Mozart's operas).
Morseau - Ein Albumblatt-Wagner.
Fantasia - French Melodieg - Kappoy.
Valse (vocal) - Queen of Hearts-Meissler.
Selection - The Dachenn of Dantzio - A. Godfrey,
Polka-Troixbopfohen-Faust.
Regimental March.
Khedivial Anthem.
God save the King.
R. Watson Ramsey. Bandmaster.

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL
div.p: Bulkeley, Ramleh.
Ten minutes from Alexandria. First-Class in every respect Very moderate charges. Bulkeley is the fashionable English quarter. Visitors fron Cairo alight at Sidi Gaber Station.
G. AQUILINA, Proprieter.

div.head: PRESENTATION TO MR. CHATAWAY
div.p: The committee of the members of the Importers Association of Alexandria presented The following address to Mr. Chataway at the Alexandria Municipality at noon to-day :
A WILLIAM PERCEVAL CHATAWAY LE COMMERCE D'IMPORTATION D'ALEXANDRIE

Monsieur,--Les élus de la ville d'Alexandrie, vous ayant appelé à de plus hautes fonctions, nous a paru à nous, négociants importateurs, qui vous avons suivi depuis votre entrée à la douane Locale, qu'il était de notre devoir de venir vous apporter le témoignage de notre Profonde estime en même temps que nos vives Félicitations. Servir le Gouvernement avec elle, en faisant toujours respecter les règlements avec une imperturbable équité, fut toujours votre rôle, mais vous avez toujours su appliquer la Loi avec une telle bienveillance dans les procédés, vous avez montré dans vos rapports avec nous, une telle urbanité et une i juste compréhension de vos devoirs, que vous avez conquis les profondes sympathies de tout le commerce dont nous sommes aujourd'hui kas interprètes et dont nous sommes chargés de vous transmettre les sincères rendements. Ce sont là des traditions que vous avez créées, et qui, nous en sommes certains, subsistent toujours. En vous disant adieu, ce n'est que la perspective d'un heureux avenir pour vous qui atténue seule les regrets que nous éprouvons de votre changement de situation.
Le Comité ; Attilio Ninci, Kamel bey Teymur,
Auguste Alby, Robert J. Rolo,
H. Steinemann, G. G. Zibilich.
The signatures of the subscribers follow.
M.Attilio Ninci made the following speech in presenting the address:

Monsieur, - Je suis heureux que mes collègues du Comité élu par les diverses branches du Commerce d'Importation de notre Ville tiennent bien vouloir me charger de prendre la parole pour vous offrir ces souvenirs et teintes de sympathie que nous vous prions d'accepter à l'occasion de votre départ comme Directeur Local de la Douane d'Alexandrie. Plus que mes paroles, l'adresse, signée par tous les souscripteurs, que nous avons l'honneur de vous présenter, vous exprimera mieux encore les sentiments et les vifs regrets que vous avez su inspirer au Commerce d'Importation en particulier. S'il ne nous a pas été permis de nous acquitter plus tôt du mandat dont nous étions chargés, ce retard est attribuable à l'exode estival d'abord, et, surtout, au désir des Membres du Comité d'être ici tous présents.

Monsieur Chataway, en prenant congé de 'ous, nous pouvons vous assurer que nos meilleurs voeux vous accompagnent dans vos nouvelles fonctions et que tous ceux qui ont eu le plaisir de se trouver en relations avec vous comme Directeur des Douanes, garderont le las agréable souvenir de votre trop bref pasage dans cette Administration.
Afterwards the committee presented the following gifts to the late Director of Local Customs :
A magnificent table service in massive silver. A cheque for L.E. 150.
A parchment address with reliefs in old silver.
An artistic work by Kerchmeyer representing the Customs Administration's façade and the offices of Mr. Chataway.

div.head: MALACHITE IN SINAI.
div.p: Professor Reisner, the well-known Egyptologist, writes to us from the Pyramids, where, as we announced, he is conducting some in"teresting excavations. He draws our attention to the fact that Professor Flinders Petrie's interest in the malachite mines of Sinai is purely archäological, and his present expedition, undertaken as usual on behalf of the Egypt Exploration Fund and approved. by that society, has a scientific purpose only. Our announcement of the professor's expedition to the malachite mines did not necessarily imply that his object was commercial instead of antiquarian. We expressed a hope that the expedition would result in reviving the export of that beautiful stone, for in Egypt, where every new development is only a re-discovery, the antiquary must precede the exploiter, as was the case with the ancient gold mines.

div.head: SINAI INSCRIPTIONS
div.p: A very interesting work is to be issued in Paris shortly dealing with the Egyptian | antiquities in the Sinaitic peninsula. The ancient Egyptian inscriptions are numerous there, but no complete description of them has yet been published. Lepsius and Lottin de Laval, about 1850, issued the first collection of Sinaitic inscriptions, and an English expedition in 1868 published some photographic reproductions of their discoveries. That there are many other finds awaiting the careful explorer silenced by the comparatively recent discoveries of Euringer and Borchatt, who, on a brief visit to the old mining districts of the peninsula, found a number of new inscriptions. M. Weill had for a long time believed that an important collection of documents from the English mission of 1868 was to be found in the British Museum, and be set about a search there which ended in the discovery of a splendid series of inscriptions which had been lying neglected for 30 years. This collection is to be republished by M. Weill and it will form ope of the finest Egypto| logical works ever published.

div.head: HELOUAN NOTES
A SUCCESSFUL SEASON
div.p: (FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT.)
Helouan December 13.
The present season at Helouan promises to be one of the best this famous health resort has ever known.

Among the latest arrival at the Grand Hotel we notice Baron and Baroness Menasce, of Alexandria, their three children, and suite, Mr. H. W. Hodges, Cairo Mr. and Mrs. Chester Master, England, Mr. C.J. R. Haswell, England, Mme. Bam Kellevink, Holland, and Mr. and Mrs. Lee, Boston, U.S.A..
Mr., Mrs. and Miss Sargent, also of Boston, have arrived and taken up their old quarters. This, we believe, is the fourth successive year that they have spent the winter at Helouan.
The Hotel des Bains reports are also good, this comfortable house being already full.
The Tewfik Palace Hotel has recently welcomed back some of its former visitors, including Major-General Lance, C. B., and Mrs. Lance.
After & course of treatment at the Sulphur Baths, Lady Loveson-Gower, and her son, Mr. Frederick Loverson-Gower M.P, for Sutherlandshire, left the Grand Hotel Helouan yesterday for a trip to Luxor.
The Hon. G. Calthorpe, Mr. Shore, and Dr. Tunnicliffe also left yesterday after a few weeks' visit. to the Grand Ho 31.

Amongst those shortly expected at the Tewfik Palace Hotel, are Irs. H. Wynne Finch, Miss Elizabeth Rich Mr. Edwin G. Owles, Mr. and Mrs. Bullock Workman, Major I. Adcock, M.D., Miss Netty Lovisa ,White, Capt. and Mrs. Hancox, Mr. and Mrs. F. F. Morley, Miss H. Rossiter, Mr. and Mrs. Craven, Mr. Whitmarsh, Mrs. Atkins, Mr. and Mrs. Willaby, Miss C. Moore, Mr. R. Page, Mrs. and Miss Robertson

div.head: FAYOUM NOTES
VISIT OF THE INTERIOR ADVISER
div.p: (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
Medinet el-Fayoum, December 12,

Mr. Machell arrived here by last night's train and made an official inspection of the town this morning accompanied by the Moudir. At 2.30 he left for Lahoon, taking with him Major Elgood, Inspector for Fayoum.

Mr. Machell did not have time to go through the province and visit the different villages in order to ascertain if the inhabitants are contented, or to hear any complaints they might want to make. He only saw the town, which of course was made read for his expected visit. He will spend the night in his dahabieh at Sidment el Gohel and is expected to reach Cairo to-morrow.
THE GHAFFIR QUESTION.
It is now proposed to appoint ghaffirs both for day and night duty and to employ retired soldiers for the service. It is understood that this plan is approved by the Adviser,
IRRIGATION.

Mr. Clowes, the newly-appointed Inspector-General for Upper Egypt, is expected here to-night. I understand that an Englishman is to replace the native moudir of the Fayoum Irrigation works, and that the pay of the district engineers is to be increased next year. This should put a stop to their receiving backsheesh, and anyone taking it should in future be severely punished.

div.head: NOTES FROM KENEH
div.p: (From our CORRESPONDENT ).
Keneh, December 9.

A Commission for the adjustment of the land taxes; composed of Mr. McKillop, the Finance inspector, president, and a staff of maoween, has arrived here with a view to add Gusting the land taxes of the locality. The maoween were, some of them, stationed in the three markazes of Keneh, Kous, and Luxor. Mr. McKillop is making a tour of inspection of the work of the maoween in these markazes. It is said the commission will complete the adjustment of the Keneh Mordirieh land taxes within 7 months, i.e., by next June.

Another commission is to be appointed after this one has finished its labours. It will be composed of the Sub-Moudir, as president, and two or three experienced codehs, to enquire into any complaints that may be made by agriculturists in connection with the increase of taxes on their lands.

div.head: NOTES FROM LUXOR
div.p: (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT).

Luxor, December 10. Mr. Shinuda Magarius, the consular agent. of Austria-Hungary, has died at his residence at Luxor. Much regret is felt by all who knew this gentleman at the loss sustained by his death.

A large number of Sudanese cattle and sheep are being sold in the market here. The animals are in great demand among the butchers as well as the farmers, owing to the great scarcity of cattle consequent on the plague's ravages.
It is hoped that these imports will have some effect in lowering the price of meat, which has reached an unprecedentedly high price.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Viscountess Hayati, wife of the Japanese Minister in England was a passenger by the North German Lloyd steamer Bayern, which passed through Port Said on Monday. Her Excellency, who is accompanied by her granddaughter, is going to Japan for the benefit of her health.

Among the passengers by the Arabia or Port Said were Sir Hugh and Lady Smiley and Lady Roberts Auslen; for Aden, Brigadier-General Sir W. H. Manning ; for Bombay, General Sir John Frye, Sir Carne Rasch, Sir Henry Cotton, Sir D..J. Ibbertson, the Ven Archdeacon Willian Sir Patrick and Lady Playfair, and Sir Herbert Stephen, Bart:

Amongst the late arrivals at the Hotel l'Angleterre are Cómte and Comtesse Crenneville, Lady Arthur Russell, Miss Flora Russell, Lady Robert Austen, Mr. and Mrs. Cormack, Mrs. Maitland, Miss Linglay, Mr. C.H.I. Mowatt, Mr C. S. Prichard, Mr. H. H. Nicol, Mr. Satasin, the Bishop of Lucknow, Mrs. Caifford, Miss Williams, Misses Young, Miss Brodie, Dr. Alex Schweizer.
Sir Elwin and Lady Palmer here for Sudan yesterday.
Chitty Bey, Director-General of Customs, returned from Cairo yesterday afternoon.

We are pleased to state that Mr. Attilio Vinci, the manager at Alexandria of the Société Generale de la Raffinerie et des Sucreries d'Egypte, has completely recovered From his recent apoplectic attack,

Over 50 of the Schewig's passengers arrived yesterday at the Savoy Hotel, Cairo, amongst whom were a great many old Savoy nabitués, including the Misses Hurley, Ms. und Mrs. Ernest Lonellow, of New York, M. und Mme. Paravicini Mr. and Mrs. E.W. Knox and the Misses Knox from Australia, Ms, and Mrs. William A. Hopin, of Providence, U.S.A, Mr. and Mrs. A. H. Olmsted and Miss Olmited, Mr. and Mrs. Walton Peckham, Mrs. M. F. Rodgers Lovell, Miss Price of Kentucky, Vr. and Miss Colebroke, of Bridgefoot, South Mimms, England, Mrs. S. C. Thompson, Mrs. 3. C. Colburn, New York, Mr. Frank de la Lanné, Philadelphia, Mrs. L. Wheaton, Providence, etc.

The following passe gors. left for the Nile trip by the P.S. Ramek at the Great yesterday : Mr. Hans Haagen; M: F. Noakes, Miss D. Noakes, Miss M. E. and Miss C. E. Turle, Miss E. and Miss H. E. Greenbalgh, Mr. and Mrs. E. Taylor, Dr. and Mrs. Milan Soulé, Mrs. C. Garrison, Miss M. C. Logan, Mrs. P. A. Wrightson, Miss I. ad Miss M. Wrightson; Mr. and Mrs. Fox, M 38 Beatrice and Miss Fannie Fox, Mr. and Irs. A. B. Lounsberry, Viscount and Viscoun38 de Galember, Mr. ind Mrs. Charles E. Arvis, Miss E. Birnie, Mrs. A. M. Birnie, Mr. M. Brocas Clay, Mys. Muriel Brocas Clay, Ms Malcolm Kerr, Miss Maddock, Mr. Liza Sommer, Mme. de Sommer, Mlle. Branca And Mile. Fernanda de Sommer, Mlle. Berthe Rollet, Mr. Luiz F. de Sommer, Miss Jeanne Rollet, Mr. R. O. Ream, Mr. H. C. Smith, Mr. W. Rabitta, Mr. E. B. Bacon,

div.head: HELOUAN REGIMENTAL SPORTS
div.p: The officers of the Royal Engineers, who are now encamped on the grounds adjoining the Tewfik Palace Hotel, Helouan, have issued invitations for a sport meeting which is to take place on Saturılay next, commencing at 2 p.m. An orchestra will be in attendance on the grounds and the grand-stand of the Helouan Sporting Club will be reserved for visitors. Tea and refreshments will be served in the magnificent lounge of the Tewfik Palace.

In connection with these sports, visitors are reminded that the “Declame" luncheon (BT. J 12) will be served at one o’clock at the Tewfik Palace Hotel. Trains leave Babel-Louk station at 9.10 am., 10.10 a.m., and 12.10 pm. Special cloak-rooms will be reserved for ladies.

div.head: REVOLUTION IN GRAMAPHONES
div.p: On the occasion of the festive season, WALKER & MEIMARAOMI, Ltd., Old Bourse Street, have received a large consignment of instruments of the very latest model from the Gramophone Co. of Milan, which they are now selling at 50 per cent below former prices.
No one should miss this chance of securing a BARGAIN. Large Assortment of Discs. 5000 in stock.

Mena House Hotel. Bracale Orchestra.
Sat. 17.-Band 2nd Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers.
Shepherd’s Hotel. 4 to 6 p.m.
Sun. 18.-Mena House Hotel. Bracale Orchestra.
